Award.AwardTitle: U.S. Participation in the International Union of Radio Science, 2013-2017
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project covers one year of support and related administrative expenses for the U.S. National Committee of the International Union of Radio Scienctists (URSI). URSI covers numerous areas of interest within the radio science discipline, including radio astronomy, materials science, physics, remote sensing, geosciences, and space sciences. The U.S. National Committee organizes a yearly conference in the U.S., and oversees the U.S. participation in international URSI activities.

URSI activities, both within the U.S. and worldwide, support the development and training of students and postdocs in numerous radio science activities in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
(NOTE:  The period of this award was shortened from 4 years to 1 year with a 1-year extension.  It, therefore, covered the years 2013-2015.)

 

The International Union for Radio Science (URSI) is one of the international scientific unions related to the International Council for Science (ICSU).  The National Academy of Sciences (NAS) is the member organization for the United States, and carries out its membership responsibilities in URSI through the U.S. National Committee for URSI (USNC-URSI).   URSI is responsible for stimulating and coordinating, on an international basis, studies, research, applications, scientific exchange, and communication in the fields of radio science. 

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

Both URSI and the USNC-URSI have ten Commissions that conduct most of the union or committee’s scientific work.  These are:

Commission A - Electromagnetic Metrology

Commission B – Fields and Waves

Commission C – Radio Communication Systems and Signal Processing

Commission D – Electronics and Photonics

Commission E – Electromagnetic Environment and Interference

Commission F – Wave Propagation and Remote Sensing

Commission G – Ionospheric Radio and Propagation

Commission H – Waves in Plasma

Commission J – Radio Astronomy

Commission K – Electromagnetics in Biology and Medicine

Not only does USNC-URSI organize an annual National Radio Science Meeting (NRSM) where research in each of these areas is presented and discussed, it also co-sponsors an annual summer meeting with the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE).  In addition, it works closely with the Canadian National Committee in organizing the North American Radio Science (NARS) meeting that brings together radio scientists from the U.S. and Canada. 

The committee also has a very active travel fellowship program supporting students and young scientists.  Several years ago, the USNC-URSI launched an annual Student Paper Competition at the NRSM, and that now has been implemented on an international level at the URSI General Assembly and Scientific Symposium (GASS) as well. The USNC-URSI runs or is highly involved in both competitions and, using private funds, provides prizes for the winners.  These competitions allow younger scientists to share their research and results.

In collaboration with URSI, the committee also administers several international prizes in radio science.  These are the Booker Award, the Booker fellowship, the Dellinger Medal, and the recently-established Santimay Basu Prize.

 

BROADER IMPACT

Research in radio science benefits society as a whole.   For example, electromagnetic interference is important for the performance of radio, TV, and navigation instruments.  Forest fires, crop yields, and soil moisture can be monitored by satellite instruments.  Space weather influences the ionosphere which, in turn, affects communication equipment and navigation.   Finally, electromagnetic fields and biological systems can interact in both harmful and beneficial ways.  Radio science is studying these causes and effects.  Ideas shared at scientific conferences at meetings like the NRSM, the URSI GASS, and the NARS meeting can lead to exchanges and collaborations from which further discoveries can be made.
